comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] It's a tower house but there's a big enough house built onto the back of it. You couldn't rule out a staff of that size if it included visitors. I suspect it may be of the upstairs crowd and the Butler just happened to have been deputised to organise it. Medals generally accrue to officers or people in their immediate environs - they're more politically awarded than people like to think, so while a batman or an NCO might have got a medal, three looks more like a lieutenant or a captain. I also suspect you have to be in control of your own destiny to have a beard like the crimean veteran on the right (unless he's the gardener, I suppose).

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The younger veteran looks like he has two South African War medals and one other. Dunno what the chap on the right has. He's the right age for it to be Crimea but it could be from anywhere in the colonies. It could equally be a police medal or something.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
The next occupant was Samuel Ferguson, a Northern Nationalist, who instituted large scale restorations at the Castle. The Keep was refaced and equipped with streamlined modern battlements, and the adjoining dwelling house was rebuilt. A door in the Coach House bears his initials and the date 1874.Under his auspices, the Butlerstown branch of the Irish National League held meetings at the Castle. After his death in 1885 the Castle passed to his son Joseph Biggar, the noted antiquarian. Amongst the guests of the Biggars at the Castle were the Gillis's of Pau, France, and the great Tim Healy himself. By a strange twist of fortune, the tenant of the younger Biggar at Butlerstown at the close of the Century was T.R. Prendergast, whose wife was a great-great-granddaughter of the last Sherlock of Butlerstown. 

Early in the present Century, the Castle was occupied by Harry Fisher , the Waterford newspaperman. The next landlords were the Nolan family of Kilronan, who installed as tenant an old lady named Hearne, who died at the age of 94, and later a family named O'Connor. Mike O'Connor was active in the Troubled Times, and in the War of Independence, frequently sheltered Volunteers in the Outhouses of the Castle. On one occassion a Volunteer named O'Rourke was wounded by the Black and Tans, who pursued him to the Butlerstown area. As the passed up and down the road searching for him, Mike O'Connor leaned against the gate, passing the time of day and making helpful suggestions. All the time he had O'Rourke hidden at the top of the Castle. During the Civil War, Butlerstown was occupied by a company of Republicans commanded by Tom Brennan of Tramore, several of the house in the area being held at this time ( 1920's ) to cover the retreat of the Republicans and delay the advance of the Free State Soldiers after the capture of Waterford. O'Connor's wife was ill at the time, and the besiegers allowed food to be hauled up in a basket to her at the top of the Castle. Eventually her condition became so critical that O’Connor persuaded the garrison to surrender.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
London Times, July 26th, 1909
At Wexford Police Court on Saturday an Indian, named Hussein Alg, in the emply of Mr Francis Boxwell, Of the Indian Civil Service, was committed to Enniscorthy lunatic Asylum for attacking his master with a sword at Butlerstown Castle, where the latter is spending his holidays. Alg took a sword from the hall and then commenced to pack up, stating that he was going to India. Mr Boxwell tried to reason with him, promising to send him home next month. Alg, however, drew the sword and attacked his master, who succeeded in holding him, despite his very violent efforts to free himself. When assistance arrived he was given into custody. The indian had been in his emply for two and a-half years. In the spring the man had been in Richmond, Dublin, Asylum, on leaving which Mr. Boxwell took him back.
The announcement of his wedding on October 12th 1905:
The marriage arranged between Mr. Frank Boxwell, of Butlerstown, Co. Wexford, and of the Bengal Police, eldest son of the late Mr John Boxwell, Commissioner of Dacca, and Ethel, younger daughter of Sir Edmund Bewley, of Fitzwilliam-place, Dublin, will take place in Dublin in November.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: In 1928 in his daughter Susan's death notice, he is described as Francis Boxwell, Esq, M.D., late of Butlerstown.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Ethel died in 1906 in Malta, and he got married again in 1913, to Charlotte Hazel St Leger

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38524006@N00] It is a little-known fact that the worldwide phenomenon known as Paint by Number started in this Picture Gallery at Kilkenny Castle in the late nineteenth century. Visitors were encouraged to choose a portrait by its number and the resident artist, Miss A. Phoole (born 1/4/1870), guided their endeavours with brushes made from the freshly-plucked hair of the gentlemen's moustaches. Art critics around the world have been arguing ever since about which pictures are original ...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38524006@N00] I'm afraid I don't know. And while I love [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia]'s explanation from 1 April(!), I hope someone on here can give you a reason - won't be half so funny, of course.
